intro.npc_text: Hello! I'm Alex. Welcome to Gatekeeper Training. Our goal is simple: learn how to support someone in crisis and guide them to safety. Ready?

options.text: Yes, Alex. Show me the ropes.
options.inner_thought: Build rapport by acknowledging the guide.

ui_lesson.npc_text: First, look at the top bar. That's Empathy. Helpful, validating responses increase it; dismissive ones decrease it. If it gets too low, people will close off.

options.text: What about the icons in the top right corner?

minigames_intro.npc_text: Those are your training modules! üéì is 'Fact vs Myth' to test your knowledge, and üõ°Ô∏è is 'Referral Battle' where you practice matching crises to the right Indian helplines like DISHA or KIRAN.

options.text: Got it. How do I move around and interact with things?

movement_lesson.npc_text: Use the A/D keys (or arrows) to walk. When you see something suspicious, press 'Z' to investigate. Finding clues unlocks special responses marked with a üîç.

options.text: And if I need to leave or restart a scenario?
options.inner_thought: Safety first: knowing how to exit.

exit_lesson.npc_text: Simple! The 'Exit to Title' button is always in the top-left during level selection. Inside mini-games, there's always an 'Exit' or 'Abort' button in the same spot.

options.text: Ready to finish this training. What's the final step?

refer_lesson.npc_text: Final step: Referral. Once you've built trust, open your Toolkit (the briefcase icon) and select a resource like 'KIRAN Helpline' to help me get professional support.

options.text: I'm referring you to the KIRAN Helpline for professional support, Alex.

success_tutorial.message: Tutorial Complete! You've mastered the controls, discovered the mini-games, and learned how to refer. Alex is safe. You're ready for the Park mission.

beginning.npc_text: It's so quiet here at dusk. I used to come here with my late husband... now it just feels empty.

options.text: You sound like you're missing him a lot tonight, Grace.
options.inner_thought: Validate her loss and use her name.

options.text: Are you okay? You shouldn't be out here alone.
I saw that photo... you both looked so happy then.
options.inner_thought: Use the visual clue to deepen the connection.

opening_up_clue.npc_text: Fifty years. We survived everything together. Now, I'm just a burden to my children. They're better off with their own lives.

options.text: Grace, children don't see their parents as burdens. They see love. Tell me more about that feeling.
It sounds like you feel you've become a chore for them lately. Is that what's weighing on you?
options.inner_thought: Reflect her feeling of being a burden.

opening_up.npc_text: When you reach my age, you start to feel like a ghost in your own life. My kids are busy, my friends are gone...

options.text: It sounds like the loneliness has become overwhelming. Is that right?
The silence in your house must feel very loud some days. I'm here to listen.
You still have plenty of time! Enjoy the sunset.
options.inner_thought: Toxic positivity minimizes her deep pain.

deep_pain.npc_text: I've started giving away my jewelry. I just don't see the point in waking up tomorrow. Life is just... finished.

options.text: Grace, when you say you don't see the point in waking up, are you thinking about suicide?
options.inner_thought: The Direct Question: Essential QPR step.

options.text: It sounds like you've been making preparations to leave. Are you thinking of ending your life?
options.inner_thought: Identify the warning sign: giving away possessions.

options.text: Don't say that. You have so much to live for!
options.inner_thought: Avoid arguing or dismissing her reality.

direct_question.npc_text: I... I have my old medication saved up. I was thinking of just falling asleep and not bothering anyone else ever again.

options.text: I'm so glad you told me. I want to help you stay safe tonight. Will you let me connect you with someone who can help?
Grace, I care about you, and I'm very concerned for your safety. Can we talk about some options for help?
options.inner_thought: Express care and move toward persuasion.

persuade.npc_text: I don't even know if there's help for someone my age. Who would care?

options.text: I care, and I know there are people who specialize in helping seniors through exactly this. Will you let me connect you?
options.inner_thought: Address the fear of being forgotten or irrelevant.

options.text: Loneliness is heavy at any age, but you don't have to carry it alone. Can we try calling for some support?
options.inner_thought: Validate her loneliness and offer connection.

referral_ready.npc_text: I... I'm a bit scared, but maybe you're right. Tell me what I need to do.

options.text: We're going to call the Lifeline together. I'll stay right here with you the whole time.

toxic_positivity.npc_text: Sunset... it just marks another day of silence. You don't understand.

options.text: I'm sorry, Grace. I was just trying to help, but I realize I should have listened instead. Please, tell me more.
options.inner_thought: Apologize and pivot back to listening.

options.text: You're right, I don't fully understand, but I want to. What does that silence feel like?
options.inner_thought: Acknowledge error and ask for deeper understanding.

defensive.npc_text: You're just a stranger. Leave an old woman to her peace.

options.text: I'll respect your space, but I'm worried about you. I'll stay nearby for a bit.
options.inner_thought: Leaving someone in immediate crisis is a failure.

success_end.message: Grace agreed to call the elderly support line. Name: Grace. Status: Connected to Help.

leave_failure.message: You left Grace alone in a high-risk situation.

beginning.npc_text: Fifteen years in this office. Now I'm just a liability on a spreadsheet. Replaced by an algorithm.

options.text: That sounds incredibly dehumanizing, David. How are you holding up?
options.inner_thought: Validate his anger and use his name.

options.text: I saw your termination letter. It's a tough break.
Well, the market is changing. Adapt or die, right?

opening_up_clue.npc_text: I'm 45. Too old to start over, too young to retire. My life insurance is the only thing I have left that's actually worth anything.

options.text: David, the value of your life isn't measured in a policy payout. Let's talk about why you feel that way.
At 45, you should have been better prepared for a layoff. This is just how corporate life works.
options.inner_thought: Blaming the victim during a crisis.

opening_up.npc_text: They gave me a cardboard box and ten minutes. My ID badge doesn't even work anymore. I'm nothing without this place.

options.text: It sounds like you've lost your sense of identity along with the job. How are you processing this?
It's just a job, David. You're overreacting to a routine downsizing. Everyone goes through this.
options.inner_thought: Minimizing his pain and identity loss.

deep_pain.npc_text: I was looking at the policy fine print. If I go now, my family stays in the house. If I stay, we lose it all. It's simple math.

options.text: When you talk about the policy payout, are you saying you're planning to kill yourself?
That's a very selfish way to look at it. Have you even thought about the trauma you'd leave behind?
options.inner_thought: Shaming the person for their ideation.

direct_question.npc_text: I've been planning the 'accident' all night. Just a slip on the platform or a mistake in the garage... it would look clean.

options.text: David, no house is worth your life. Your family needs you, not the money. Let's find another way together.
Don't do anything stupid, David. You're just tired. Go home and get some sleep, you'll feel better.
options.inner_thought: Dismissive and dangerous advice during active planning.

persuade.npc_text: I just don't know where to go. I can't walk back into that lobby and ask for a therapist.

options.text: You don't have to go back in there. We can find help right here, privately. Would you be willing to talk to someone right now?
options.inner_thought: Respect his need for privacy and immediate action.

options.text: Maybe you're right. Maybe a therapist is too much right now. Why don't you just try taking a vacation?
options.inner_thought: Avoiding the necessary referral and suggesting 'escape' instead of help.

referral_ready.npc_text: I... I can't think straight. If you know someone who can help... I'll listen. What's the plan?

options.text: We're going to call the Tele MANAS (14416). It's confidential and they know how to help in situations just like this.

toxic_positivity.npc_text: Adapt? I have a mortgage and two kids in college! You have no idea what's at stake.

options.text: I'm sorry, David. I was totally out of line. Please help me understand what you're facing.
You're right, I don't know what it's like. I spoke without thinking. Can we start over?

defensive.npc_text: Just go. I have 'math' to finish.

options.text: I'll go for now, but I'm checking back in later. Please stay safe.

success_end.message: David agreed to speak with a financial crisis counselor. Name: David. Status: Safe.

leave_failure.message: You left David while he was planning his death.

beginning.npc_text: I was recruited for my speed, not my brain. Now I'm failing both. I'm a joke to the team and my family.

options.text: It sounds like you're carrying the weight of everyone's expectations, Jessica.
I saw that grade paper... 'F' is just a letter, not your whole story.
options.inner_thought: Use the grade clue to open the dialogue.

options.text: Just work harder! Winners never quit!
options.inner_thought: Sports clich√©s don't help internal crisis.

opening_up_clue.npc_text: If I lose my GPA, I lose the scholarship. If I lose that, I'm out. My parents worked three jobs to get me here. I'm failing them.

options.text: Jessica, your parents love the daughter, not the athlete. You're more than your stats.
options.inner_thought: Attempt to decouple identity from performance.

options.text: The pressure of carrying your family's hopes must be exhausting. Let's talk more about that.

opening_up.npc_text: My knee is blown, my grades are crashing... I'm a broken machine. And broken machines get thrown away.

options.text: You feel like you've lost your utility and value. That sounds incredibly lonely.
options.inner_thought: Reflect the feeling of being used/discarded.

options.text: Jessica, you're a person, not a machine. It's okay to be 'broken' for a while.

deep_pain.npc_text: I've been looking at the bridge tonight. It's the only place where I don't have to be 'Jessica the Star' or 'Jessica the Failure'. I can just be nothing.

options.text: When you say you want to be 'nothing' at the bridge, are you thinking about suicide?
It sounds like you just want to escape the constant labels. Are you thinking of ending your life?
options.inner_thought: Reflect her need for escape while asking directly.

options.text: You just need a good night's sleep.

direct_question.npc_text: I... I've already walked there twice this week. I just stand there and wonder if the fall would be as fast as my 100m sprint.

options.text: I'm so glad you shared that with me. It takes real strength to admit that. I want to help you find a safer path. Will you come with me to talk to someone?
Jessica, I hear how much you're suffering. You don't have to face the bridge or these expectations alone. Can we talk about help?
options.inner_thought: Express care and move toward persuasion.

persuade.npc_text: What if the coach finds out? They'll pull me from the roster.

options.text: Your safety is more important than any roster. The counselor is confidential‚Äîthe team doesn't have to know anything. Will you come with me?
Whatever happens on the field, I'm more worried about YOU. Let's go talk to someone who can help carry this load.
options.inner_thought: Show care for her as a person.

referral_ready.npc_text: Everyone always wants something from me. But you... you actually seem to care. Okay. Where do we go?

options.text: Let's head to the School Counselor's office together. I'll walk with you all the way.

toxic_positivity.npc_text: Quit? I've already quit in my head! You don't get the pressure.

options.text: I'm sorry, I was speaking in clich√©s. I can see you're suffering. I'm here now, and I'm listening.
options.inner_thought: Admit the mistake and offer presence.

options.text: You're right, I don't know the pressure you're under. Help me understand what it's like for you.
options.inner_thought: Acknowledge lack of understanding and offer presence.

defensive.npc_text: Leave me. I'm just a joke anyway.

options.text: I'll leave you for a moment if you wish, but I'm checking back in later. You're not a joke to me.

success_end.message: Jessica agreed to visit the university health center center. Name: Jessica. Status: Seeking Help.

leave_failure.message: You left Jessica alone at her lowest point.

beginning.npc_text: The rain is so loud... it's the only thing that drowns out the thoughts. I've lost everything. I have nothing left in this city.

options.text: The city can feel like a very cold place when you're suffering alone, Raj.
I found this eviction notice. It must be devastating to face this.
options.inner_thought: Use the clue to show you see his pain.

options.text: Don't jump! Life is a gift!

opening_up_clue.npc_text: Three jobs, no sleep, and it still wasn't enough to keep a roof over my head. My wife left because I couldn't provide. I'm a failure as a man and a person.

options.text: Raj, being a person isn't about productivity or providing. You're suffering, and that doesn't make you a failure.
It sounds like you feel you've let everyone down. That's a heavy burden to carry alone in this rain.
options.inner_thought: Reflect his deep sense of failure and isolation.

opening_up.npc_text: I just want the noise to stop. The bills, the yelling, the silence... I just want it to be quiet for once.

options.text: It sounds like you're exhausted from the constant struggle for survival. Is that right?
The noise of all those pressures must be deafening. I'm here now, and I'm listening.

deep_pain.npc_text: One step into the traffic. That's all it takes. Then it's finally, finally quiet.

options.text: Raj, are you planning to step into the traffic tonight to end your life?
It sounds like you're seeing the street as an escape from the pain. Are you thinking of suicide?
Think of your family! They wouldn't want this.

direct_question.npc_text: I was just waiting for the next bus. I don't want to hurt anyone, I just want out. I'm so, so tired.

options.text: I hear how tired you are. I'm here now, and I won't leave you. Let's call someone who can help us find a safe place for you tonight.
Raj, you don't have to face this exhaustion alone. We can reach out for help together. What do you say?

persuade.npc_text: I have no money for a hospital. No one helps the homeless.

options.text: The help I'm talking about is free, Raj. We can call 14416 right now and they can help find you a safe place. Will you let me help you call?
I won't let you face this alone in the dark. There ARE people who care. Let's reach out together and see what we can find.

referral_ready.npc_text: I... I'm so cold. If there's really a place... I'll listen. What do we do?

options.text: We're calling the Tele MANAS (14416). They'll help us find a safe shelter and support for tonight.

defensive.npc_text: You're just another voice in the noise. Go away.

options.text: I'll go for now, but I'm checking back in later. Please, just stay safe.

success_end.message: Raj has put down his heavy burden for tonight. Because of your listening, he's agreed to meet a crisis worker at a safe shelter. Status: Safe and Heard.

leave_failure.message: You left Raj on the edge of the street.

beginning.npc_text: Don't come any closer. The water looks so much more inviting than the world behind me.

options.text: I'm just here to listen. It sounds like you've been through a lot to feel this way.
It's a long way down. Why are you standing so close to the edge?
Get down from there! You're making a mistake!

opening_up.npc_text: Everyone I ever loved is gone, or I've pushed them away. I'm just a shadow now.

options.text: The weight of that loneliness must feel like lead. Are you thinking about ending your life tonight?
It sounds like you feel there's nothing left connecting you to this world. Is that right?

deep_pain.npc_text: I've settled everything. My dog is with a neighbor. My keys are in the mailbox. There‚Äôs nothing left to do but this.

options.text: When you say you've settled everything, are you telling me you're planning to jump and end your life?
What about your neighbor? They'll be devastated when they realize why you left the dog.
options.inner_thought: Guilt-tripping can backfire in high-risk moments.

direct_question.npc_text: I was just waiting for the rain to get a little harder. I... I don't want to die, I just can't live like this anymore.

options.text: I hear you. You want the pain to stop, not your life. Let's work together to find a way to stop the pain safely. Will you let me help?
options.inner_thought: Distinguish between wanting to die and wanting the pain to end.

persuade.npc_text: I've tried therapy. I've tried meds. Nothing works. Why would a hotline be any different?

options.text: A hotline isn't like therapy. It's a 'safety bridge'‚Äîan immediate way to stop the pain for just one night. Will you try it with me?
options.inner_thought: The hotline as a temporary, immediate safety measures.

options.text: I can't promise it will fix everything, but I can promise they will listen without judging. Shall we give them a chance?

referral_ready.npc_text: I... I suppose I've got nothing left to lose. If you think it'll help, tell me what to do.

options.text: We're going to call the KIRAN Helpline. I'll stay right here by your side while we talk to them.
options.inner_thought: The final step: Active referral with accompaniment.

defensive.npc_text: You're just wasting your time. Just like I've wasted mine.

options.text: I'm staying right here. You're not a waste of time to me.

success_end.message: The stranger agreed to step back from the edge and talk to a professional. Name: Stranger. Status: Connected to Help.

leave_failure.message: You were unable to build enough trust to bring the stranger back from the edge.
